text:
Email topic ahead:

I'm subscribed to very few newsletters from SaaS companies.

The reason being most of them follow the same structure:

1. Here's what we published recently
2. Some product updates

On point 1, unless your brand has strong thought leadership and you're able to get "writers" who are well-known SMEs, people won't really care about this content.

On point 2, most of your subscribers will want actual resources and hands-on tips/info from your newsletters, not a product pitch.

Keep your product updates for a separate email you send to users, in-app messages, and, the missing piece with so many SaaS tools, a changelog.

This could well be an ode to why you need a changelog, but we'll keep that for another day.

So what do you do to make your newsletters worthwhile?

Think of them as a stand-alone product.

- give people a reason to open your newsletter every time
- provide unique content by "gating" it behind your newsletter subscription
- avoid the temptation of curating everything
- choose to provide tips, use cases, opinionated posts, and other unique content over reposting

This is the key to building a newsletter that can accumulate thousands of subscribers and help you build a niche brand following.

Way more ROI in this than pushing your product forward.

How do your newsletters stand out?

How do your newsletters stand out?

text:
I set up 30-minute calls with SMEs and interview them, then ghostwrite articles for them based on the conversation. Even the most strapped-for-time exec would rather give you 30 minutes and get multiple articles out of it than spend hours trying to write the articles themselves.

Bonus: If you do a video call, sometimes you end up getting good sound bite clips for social media too.

elements.text:
I set up 30-minute calls with SMEs and interview them, then ghostwrite articles for them based on the conversation. Even the most strapped-for-time exec would rather give you 30 minutes and get multiple articles out of it than spend hours trying to write the articles themselves.

Bonus: If you do a video call, sometimes you end up getting good sound bite clips for social media too.

text: I don’t think it’s an either/or situation. You can create an in-depth ebook *and* repurpose each of its sections as smaller blog and social posts.

elements.text: I don’t think it’s an either/or situation. You can create an in-depth ebook
and
repurpose each of its sections as smaller blog and social posts.

text:
Agreed with <@U02ME70EHBL> here. That’s something we’ve found works especially when you want to capture demand from specific searches and get them to a particular article but then want to cater to people who would rather consume content in one long-form piece.

Tag the articles, compile them into an ebook they can download and add it as an opt-in to each spoke page.

We’ve usually compile all the content into one long-form page that we `noindex` but promote on the spoke pages as an ultimate guide (this avoids the issues you run into where ultimate guides don’t match the broad search intent and would otherwise cause the pages to compete with one another).

We lean toward this approach vs ebook because we care more about content consumption than lead gen. 

*It depends on the behavior of your specific audience though.* 

We just found that the ebook route resulted in a few things: 

1. Plenty of leads that never converted (<0.3%), which just meant wasted time and money spent on building marketing automation sequences and BDR/SDR cadences.
2. Lack of consumption. We surveyed people and learned many downloaded the ebooks who never read them…which wasn't surprising when we stepped back and thought about our underlying assumptions about how to market and sell.
    a. I remember creating a tag on my Mac to tag all the ebooks for that one day in the future when I would read them. :man-facepalming:
When we compared the performance data from the long-form content with the gated content route, they were better. 

We also gained the added benefit of getting consumption data in the form of time on page, activity (scroll depth, mouse tracking, next page, exit page, etc.).


Which is really useful on the marketing automation/sales cadence side of things—especially when you know who the visitor is from some prior opt-in and such.


The idea being if we’re going to have BDRs spend time trying nurture relationships, they might as well focus on the people that are actually consuming the content and showing other high-intent behaviors (e.g. spent x min on page + scrolled y % + visited an additional high intent page—pricing, demo, etc.).

> *But to be clear*, I still think ebooks can be useful and have their place. Just that it’s worth testing and comparing to see what works best with your audience.

elements.text: Agreed with

here. That’s something we’ve found works especially when you want to capture demand from specific searches and get them to a particular article but then want to cater to people who would rather consume content in one long-form piece.

Tag the articles, compile them into an ebook they can download and add it as an opt-in to each spoke page.

We’ve usually compile all the content into one long-form page that we
noindex

but promote on the spoke pages as an ultimate guide (this avoids the issues you run into where ultimate guides don’t match the broad search intent and would otherwise cause the pages to compete with one another).

We lean toward this approach vs ebook because we care more about content consumption than lead gen.
It depends on the behavior of your specific audience though.
We just found that the ebook route resulted in a few things:
Plenty of leads that never converted (<0.3%), which just meant wasted time and money spent on building marketing automation sequences and BDR/SDR cadences.

Lack of consumption. We surveyed people and learned many downloaded the ebooks who never read them…which wasn't surprising when we stepped back and thought about our underlying assumptions about how to market and sell.
I remember creating a tag on my Mac to tag all the ebooks for that one day in the future when I would read t
hem.

When we compared the performance data from the long-form content with the gated content route, they were better. 

We also gained the added benefit of getting consumption data in the form of time on page, activity (scroll depth, mouse tracking, next page, exit page, etc.).


Which is really useful on the marketing automation/sales cadence side of things—especially when you know who the visitor is from some prior opt-in and such.


The idea being if we’re going to have BDRs spend time trying nurture relationships, they might as well focus on the people that are actually consuming the content and showing other high-intent behaviors (e.g. spent x min on page + scrolled y % + visited an additional high intent page—pricing, demo, etc.).
But to be clear
, I still think ebooks can be useful and have their place. Just that it’s worth testing and comparing to see what works best with your audience.

text:
I wish Asana would put more effort into their “Files” tab in the project view. It'd be wonderful if it had more organization features and even better if you could aggregate files up to the team/portfolio/organization level…

Also, I just realized we could automate getting attachments from Asana tasks into Airtable using the API using the `attachment object`. :star-struck:

attachment object

text: The freelance contractor - is it going to be just 1 person because typically if budget allows I would hire an editor and writer separately because while both are involved in the content writing process but bring something slightly different to the table. Also, I am not sure what your overall social media strategy is but I would look to allocate in your budget video content marketing practices as well. It expands the reach beyond just the written text.

Also, I am not sure what your overall social media strategy is but I would look to allocate in your budget video content marketing practices as well. It expands the reach beyond just the written text.

text: Yeah, I don’t think Asana will work for us due to the lack of functionality but I want to see what we can do before bringing on _another_ platform. Seems like we might just have to though!

another

text:
Depending on the content and age of the website, here's some other things to consider:
• SEO copyeditor / brief builder -- you can have someone create outlines / briefs for your writers to use. And/or apply final touches before publishing
• Graphic illustrator -- improves the legitimacy of your content with custom illustrations
• Video creator -- some categories of keywords are enhanced with video embeds
• Link builder -- if your domain is just getting off the ground, a few links from relevant websites will accelerate your content's ability to rank

elements.text: Depending on the content and age of the website, here's some other things to consider:
SEO copyeditor / brief builder -- you can have someone create outlines / briefs for your writers to use. And/or apply final touches before publishing
Graphic illustrator -- improves the legitimacy of your content with custom illustrations
Video creator -- some categories of keywords are enhanced with video embeds
Link builder -- if your domain is just getting off the ground, a few links from relevant websites will accelerate your content's ability to rank

text: <@U030W3J5CBT> A mix. Development of visual assets/images/messaging and execution of the content are the biggest pain points.

elements.text: A mix. Development of visual assets/images/messaging and execution of the content are the biggest pain points.

text: Really good tips here already. Not much for me to add, but I will note that a solid outline of questions for them to answer + Loom has done the trick for me personally.

text: The best tool/process is going to be the one everyone uses and follows. One single catalog, organized in a way your team can navigate to when they need to. Lots of ways to catalog assets and content, but this is where more advanced tools like Bynder and Brandfolder shine.

elements.text: The best tool/process is going to be the one everyone uses and follows. One single catalog, organized in a way your team can navigate to when they need to. Lots of ways to catalog assets and content, but this is where more advanced tools like Bynder and Brandfolder shine.

text: A desperate cry for help…a couple days ago, I saw a great Twitter thread about what to say to your boss when they’re reluctant to share internal knowledge as a marketing strategy. Folks were chiming in with examples of companies that used this tactic successfully. Does anybody know the tweet I’m referring to? Or otherwise have examples they’d like to share?

text:
How do you approach keyword research and content planning when you’re doing the research in English, the articles will get written in English, but the final articles will get translated into other languages?

Would you do kw research for English? Or kw research the country/language into which those articles will get translated? :thinking_face:

elements.text:
How do you approach keyword research and content planning when you’re doing the research in English, the articles will get written in English, but the final articles will get translated into other languages?

Would you do kw research for English? Or kw research the country/language into which those articles will get translated?

text: Hi Nik! I’m Content Manager for French markets, and the best practice is to do the keyword research for each final language. Doing only EN and then translation can work, but you will miss a lot of keyword opportunities.

elements.text: Hi Nik! I’m Content Manager for French markets, and the best practice is to do the keyword research for each final language. Doing only EN and then translation can work, but you will miss a lot of keyword opportunities.
